newsitem.title: GERMANY: Dresdner optimistic after first quarter.
newsitem.headline: Dresdner optimistic after first quarter.

text.p: Germany's Dresdner Bank AG said on Friday that it was cautiously optimistic for 1997 after a good first quarter and expected to post a result for the full year that would allow an attractive dividend.

"Although the environment remains difficult for the German banks in 1997, after a good first quarter we remain cautiously optimistic for the full year," chairman Juergen Sarrazin told the bank's annual general meeting.
Sarrazin said Dresdner, Germany's second largest commercial bank, increased its operating profit before risk provisions by 10 percent to 991 million marks ($586.4 million) in the first quarter.
"We are also confident of being able to present a full year
1997 result which will enable us to pay an attractive dividend as well as significantly increase our reserves," Sarrazin said.
"Once again in 1997, given the opportunity, we will continue to transfer some of the unrealised reserves in our non-bank holdings to strengthen equity," he said.

Dresdner raised its 1996 dividend to 1.45 marks per share from 1.35 marks and also paid a bonus dividend of 10 pfennigs to mark its 125th anniversary, as its net profit rose 31 percent to 1.58 billion marks.
Sarrazin said earnings in the first quarter of 1997 had as usual been influenced by special factors and could not be directly extrapolated for the full year.
The bank posted a particularly strong rise in commission income for the three-month period, with a 20.6 percent rise to 1.2 billion marks on the back of high equity and mutual fund sales.
Net interest income rose rose 8.8 percent to 1.7 billion marks, but was partly boosted by elements of "quasi-trading income", Sarrazin said, which were not necessarily sustainable over the full year.

Own account trading income was 330 million marks, which Sarrazin said was very satisfactory, without providing a comparative figure. The first quarter result was, however, equal to half the full trading income for 1996.
Administrative costs rose 10.4 percent to 2.3 billion marks, partly due to the first-time consolidation of RCM Capital Management, without which the rise would have been 7.3 percent.
